title: feat: bump MSRV to 1.58 (because of dependencies)
Move to `async/.await`
body:
Hi,

As I am currently working with some OpenStack services, I was looking for a way to interact with these from Rust code, and stumbled upon this SDK, which is quite extensive already.  
But being interested in using it in an async context, the fact that the IO operations in the SDK were done synchronously made it a bit suboptimal to adopt.

This PR follows in the footsteps of the previous `async` branch, and completes the refactoring it started across the entire SDK.  

It makes every operation asynchronous, which involved:
- replacing `Read` and `Write` by `AsyncRead` and `AsyncWrite` respectively
- replacing `FallibleIterator` by `TryStream`
- annotating most traits with `#[async_trait]`

This PR comes with the following two other PRs, which are needed to successfully compile:
- [**#68**] for `rust-osauth` which publicly exposes its `stream` module to allow using its `PaginatedResource` trait
- [**#1**] for `rust-waiter` which makes its `waiter` trait async (also using `async_trait`)

[**#68**]: https://github.com/dtantsur/rust-osauth/pull/68
[**#1**]: https://github.com/dtantsur/rust-waiter/pull/1

As I have currently only worked with the object storage parts of OpenStack, I am not sure of how to properly test for the other parts of the SDK, such as the `network`, `image` and `compute` features.  
The code changes were done such that its behaviour should remain unchanged, but I haven't tested these on my own machine yet.

title: chore: prepare 0.4.1, update MSRV
refactor: import sync.rs from osauth in preparation for its removal
chore(ci): use github actions for functional tests
[Object store] add hash to objects
body:
This PR:

* add some examples about object stores: 
    * list containers, 
    * and list the first 10 objects of a given container;
* add hash to objects

## About object's hash property

The hash of an object [is described as the following](https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/?expanded=get-object-content-and-metadata-detail#get-object-content-and-metadata):

> For objects smaller than 5 GB, this value is the MD5 checksum of the object content. The value is not quoted. For manifest objects, this value is the MD5 checksum of the concatenated string of ETag values for each of the segments in the manifest, and not the MD5 checksum of the content that was downloaded. Also the value is enclosed in double-quote characters. You are strongly recommended to compute the MD5 checksum of the response body as it is received and compare this value with the one in the ETag header. If they differ, the content was corrupted, so retry the operation.

The value is presented:

* under the "hash" key [when listing objects in a container](https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/?expanded=get-object-content-and-metadata-detail,show-container-details-and-list-objects-detail#show-container-details-and-list-objects) (request `/v1/{account}/{container}`;
* as the `ETag` header, [when requesting a single object](https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/?expanded=get-object-content-and-metadata-detail#get-object-content-and-metadata), (request `/v1/{account}/{container}/{object}`).

`hash` is kept for naming the property.

## Examples

This PR add examples for listing containers and objects.

title: Add url method to Object

Add a method for retreiving object url, because when creating an object (in object storage) there was no way to retreive the url.

As stated in my previous pull request, I begin in rust and would appreciate any comments to improve the pull request.

title: Object Storage: add availability to use custom headers
body:
First I want to thank you for your lib.

I add the availibitily to send custom headers during an object creation. This allows for exemple to use 'X-Delete-After' for adding a ttl to the object.
I choose to send headers, this way there is more flexibility and everyone can use the headers he wants based on the openstack doc.

I just start developping in rust from few days, so I didn't publish tests with it (though I have tested it with a personnal project). Also feel free to give me some comments and I will be glad to improve it.

in NewNetwork. It is now added to NewNetwork as well to allow creation

title: Implement basic Object Storage support (closes #91)
Use rustls instead of native-tls to avoid non-Rust dependencies
body:
This might need a couple of iterations before you're happy with it, but let's see.

I'm using rust-openstack in an internal tool, and I want to be able to build it into a binary with as few dependencies as possible that can run on lots of systems. Currently that's a bit painful because it depends on the system openssl library, and isn't portable between e.g. Ubuntu and Centos systems if they have slightly different OpenSSL library versions.

https://github.com/ctz/rustls is a pure-Rust HTTPS library, so avoids the system openssl dependency, and reqwest exposes a feature to use that for HTTPS instead.

`rusoto_ec2` takes an approach of exposing `rustls` and `native-tls` features so users can explicitly choose between them. I worry that would be a bit fiddlier for rust-openstack, because to switch to rustls someone would need to:

- disable default features
- re-enable the sensible defaults - compute, image and network, plus the sync feature from osauth that we'd need to re-export
- also enable the rustls feature

Given that overhead I'd like to suggest just switching to rustls by default, and only exposing a flag if some other user really wants to use native-tls - but I might be overly-focused on making my use-case easy, so you're welcome to disagree and I'll put in feature flags.

title: feat: update to reqwest 0.9 (some breaking changes)
body:
Taking this opportunity to rely less on the exact reqwest API.

BREAKING CHANGES:
* Custom `RequestBuilder` is removed in favor of `RequestBuilderExt`
  extension trait on top of `reqwest::RequestBuilder`.
* `AuthMethod::request` and `Session::request` now return
  `Result<RequestBuilder>` with `RequestBuilder` from `reqwest`.
* `Identity::new` and `NoAuth::new` now return the `Result` (using
   `openstack::Error` as the error type).
* Changed `ServiceType::api_version_headers` to `set_api_version_headers`
  to stop using `reqwest` headers type in the signature.
